```{r}
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)
library(readxl)

# Load your dataset
warehouse_logistics_analysis <- read_excel("C:/Users/jacob/OneDrive/Desktop/R Studio Projects 2024/Datasets/warehouse_logistics_analysis.xlsx")

# Define the predictor (x) and response (y) variables
x <- warehouse_logistics_analysis$Shipment_Volume
y <- warehouse_logistics_analysis$Cost

# Fit a linear model
linear_model <- lm(y ~ x, data = warehouse_logistics_analysis)

# Create the plot for the linear model
linear_plot <- ggplot(warehouse_logistics_analysis, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(warehouse_logistics_analysis$Shipment_Volume), linetype = "dotted", color = "red") +
  ggtitle("Linear Model: Cost vs. Shipment Volume") +
  theme_minimal()

# Fit a quadratic model
quadratic_model <- lm(y ~ poly(x, 2, raw = TRUE), data = warehouse_logistics_analysis)

# Create the plot for the quadratic model
quadratic_plot <- ggplot(warehouse_logistics_analysis, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point() +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ poly(x, 2, raw = TRUE), se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(warehouse_logistics_analysis$Shipment_Volume), linetype = "dotted", color = "red") +
  ggtitle("Quadratic Model: Cost vs. Shipment Volume") +
  theme_minimal()

# Combine both plots into one figure
grid.arrange(linear_plot, quadratic_plot, ncol = 1)

```
